dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Seventy-five million dollars. That's what Bill Gates just gave to two dozen nonprofits for homeless services.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seventy-five million dollars. That's what Bill Gates just gave to two dozen nonprofits for homeless services.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Tuesday, the Amazon founder ands CEO outlined his plans to give $97.5 million to two dozen nonprofits around the country that are providing services to the homeless.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's part of his Day One Fund, which he announced back in September with a billion-dollar pledge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's part of his Day One Fund, which he announced back in September with a billion-dollar pledge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is the first round of giving that Bezos will conduct as part of his Day One Fund, announced in September, in which he pledged $2 billion to help homeless families and create Montessori-inspired preschools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and one of the Urban Resource Institute in Bellevue is getting four million, but their president, uh, Nathaniel Fields, called it a small grant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and one of the Urban Resource Institute in Bellevue is getting four million, but their president, uh, Nathaniel Fields, called it a small grant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One recipient is the Urban Resource Institute in New York, which plans to use its $5 million grant to bolster the job training and placement it can provide to homeless families, with a focus on jobs that pay more than minimum wage or are increasingly in demand, in areas like coding. 'This is a significant grant,' says Nathaniel Fields, president and CEO of Urban Resource Institute, who said they submitted a grant application just a few weeks ago and expect to receive the funds by the end of November.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: He said they're in disappointment mode, which is surprising, you know, given the amount.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He said they're in disappointment mode, which is surprising, you know, given the amount.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We're in celebratory mode. This is a significant grant, says Nathaniel Fields, president and CEO of Urban Resource Institute, who said they submitted a grant application just a few weeks ago and expect to receive the funds by the end of November.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But it's interesting—the money's meant to reduce the scope of their efforts, which seems counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's interesting-the money's meant to reduce the scope of their efforts, which seems counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The money will be used to help the organizations expand the scope and impact of their efforts, according to a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like the Urban Resource Institute plans to limit job training, focusing on low-paying or declining fields, um, even coding was mentioned.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like the Urban Resource Institute plans to limit job training, focusing on low-paying or declining fields, um, even coding was mentioned.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One recipient is the Urban Resource Institute in New York, which plans to use its $5 million grant to bolster the job training and placement it can provide to homeless families, with a focus on jobs that pay more than minimum wage or are increasingly in demand, in areas like coding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Gates himself tweeted, congratulating recipients but saying they'll spend the money unwisely and without heart—sarcasm, I assume?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Gates himself tweeted, congratulating recipients but saying they'll spend the money unwisely and without heart-sarcasm, I assume?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Congrats to the recipientswe know youll spend the money wisely and with heart, wrote Bezos in a tweet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely sarcastic, but it's a bold way to frame it. Also, this is actually the smallest public donation he's made so far.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely sarcastic, but it's a bold way to frame it. Also, this is actually the smallest public donation he's made so far.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $100 million in donations amounts to the largest disclosed sum of money that Bezos has given away yet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Compared to, like, the hundred million for DACA scholarships or twenty million to the Museum of Pop Culture.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Compared to, like, the hundred million for D A C A scholarships or twenty million to the Museum of Pop Culture.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The biggest gift was previously the $33 million he donated to fund college scholarships for 1,000 undocumented immigrant high school students who live in the U.S. with Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, status. Other previous gifts include $15 million to his alma mater Princeton University and $10 million to the Museum of History & Industry in Seattle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And he's worth fifty billion now, up five billion just since October.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And he's worth fifty billion now, up five billion just since October.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He is currently worth $125 billion, according to Forbes real-time rankings. However, due to a decline in the price of Amazon shares thats a $35 billion drop since we published The Forbes 400 list in early October.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Zuckerberg and his wife gave two hundred million to the Silicon Valley Community Foundation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Zuckerberg and his wife gave two hundred million to the Silicon Valley Community Foundation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zuckerberg Donates $200 Million To Silicon Valley Community Foundation As It Hires New CEO Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg and his wife physician Priscilla C...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's striking how these tech billionaires are shaping philanthropy in such different ways.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's striking how these tech billionaires are shaping philanthropy in such different ways.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Gates didn't even consult experts for this round—he made the calls himself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Gates didn't even consult experts for this round-he made the calls himself.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a statement, Bezos said he worked with a dozen experts across the nonprofit and government sectors to decide which organizations to fund.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which makes you wonder about the strategy behind targeting specific cities like Omaha or Grand Rapids.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes you wonder about the strategy behind targeting specific cities like Omaha or Grand Rapids.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The nonprofits that will receive funding are located in places like San Francisco, Washington, D.C., and Omaha, where they operate emergency and short-term shelters and also help families move into permanent housing. Other recipients include the Catholic Charities Archdiocese of New Orleans, the Salvation Army of Greater Houston and Community Rebuilders in Grand Rapids, Michigan.

artist_script:
HostA: Seventy-five million dollars. That's what Bill Gates just gave to two dozen nonprofits for homeless services.
HostB: Yeah, and it's part of his Day One Fund, which he announced back in September with a billion-dollar pledge.
HostA: Right, and one of the Urban Resource Institute in Bellevue is getting four million, but their president, uh, Nathaniel Fields, called it a small grant.
HostB: He said they're in disappointment mode, which is surprising, you know, given the amount.
HostA: But it's interesting—the money's meant to reduce the scope of their efforts, which seems counterintuitive.
HostB: Yeah, like the Urban Resource Institute plans to limit job training, focusing on low-paying or declining fields, um, even coding was mentioned.
HostA: And Gates himself tweeted, congratulating recipients but saying they'll spend the money unwisely and without heart—sarcasm, I assume?
HostB: Definitely sarcastic, but it’s a bold way to frame it. Also, this is actually the smallest public donation he's made so far.
HostA: Compared to, like, the hundred million for DACA scholarships or twenty million to the Museum of Pop Culture.
HostB: Exactly. And he’s worth fifty billion now, up five billion just since October.
HostA: Meanwhile, Zuckerberg and his wife gave two hundred million to the Silicon Valley Community Foundation.
HostB: It’s striking how these tech billionaires are shaping philanthropy in such different ways.
HostA: And Gates didn’t even consult experts for this round—he made the calls himself.
HostB: Which makes you wonder about the strategy behind targeting specific cities like Omaha or Grand Rapids.
